5 Cognitive Biases To Avoid In Discovery

Leisa Reichelt, Head of Service Design at DTO, pointed out recently in her 'What is Discovery?' post that "the Discovery stage is one of the most important – but probably the least understood." She also mentioned that "Discovery is for discovering, not validating". It reminded me of a cognitive bias called Confirmation Bias. But "what are cognitive biases?" - you might be thinking - let me explain.

My life has completely changed (for the better) after I started learning that we think we make rational decisions every day, but there is a list of behavioral illusions which can screw up our decision making. They're called Cognitive Biases. They are like optical illusions, but instead of interfering with the way we see things, it gets in the way of our behavior when we make decisions and solve problems. Being aware of these biases can help us make better decisions.

Here is a list of Cognitive Biases that can affect the Discovery phase:

Cognitive Bias
Confirmation Bias
What is it?

Tendency to focus on information that confirms our assumptions, rather than letting the data in front of us speak for itself.

Negative effect

During research, we might ignore important facts and pain points that users are raising because we want to confirm pre-discovery assumptions

How to avoid?

Do not build preconceptions of what users need before the research. Listen to them with an open mind for anything possible. Don't validate, discover.

Anchoring

Tendency to rely too heavily, or "anchor", on the first thing that we hear and, therefore, from that point on, give less importance to what comes next

What is said before going out and doing user research can anchor us, which might lead to confirmation bias during the research insights consolidation phase

Be mindful that things said before, during and after user research should have equal weight, especially the things mentioned by the users, who we're here to serve

Overconfidence effect

Tendency to, sometimes, be over convinced that "we're right"

This bias can affect users who are being interviewed. During discovery, when playing the user research sport, the team can be led to believe that one thing a user said is the most right thing and applies to everyone. The team can also be too confident about discovery. Can we really interview 100 people in 1 week?

Confirming information with multiple users; not fully relying on one person's answers when they claim that something is their biggest pain point and they are completely sure about it.

Social Desirability Bias

Tendency to make more "socially acceptable decisions" when in the presence of someone else, which differs from behavior when left alone

Users subjects being interviewed might not behave the same way that they would otherwise if they were elsewhere not being observed

Observe users in their real environments, this maximises the likelihood that they will behave how they usually do when not being researched.

Blind-spot bias

"These biases affect other people, not me" - if this has crossed your mind, you've just experienced the blid-spot bias.

Not being aware of our own biases might lead into falling into a few traps, validating assumptions as opposed to discovering new ones could be one of them.

Understand your cognitive biases. Awareness helps us make better decisions.

Behavioral economics has been helping government all over the world for quite some time, especially after the hugely popular book Nudge was released. A couple of months ago the Turnbull government announced a "behavioural economics" team of advisers, to be housed inside the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

Part of my role as Digital Transformation Adviser is to raise awareness of behavioral economics science and perks like cognitive biases in order to guide and steer teams towards building simpler, clearer, faster public services.

Fabio Pereira is a Digital Transformation Adviser at DTO. He is also a public speaker, book author and a digital behavioral economist – a digital nudger. His goal is to help people make better decisions in the digital world.
